Reflecting on Tesla's rise ahead of a possible addition to the S&P 500 Index, one conclusion seems inescapable: Index funds are dumb money *by design*.

Every investor paying a nosebleed valuation today (let's say in excess of 10-20x sales) needs to ask, "Why is my company analogous to Amazon?" If the answer is not absolutely clear, beware what's coming to the average market darling of today.

The perfect historical example is $AMZN. However, unfortunately, the Amazon analogy does not apply to the vast majority of today's market darlings. The latter have a temporary rather than a permanent competitive advantage.
Be a "learn it all," not a "know it all."  Great point, made by ValueAct CIO and former Microsoft board member Mason Morfit:   https://t.co/LvemQg5b13

@4drant One way of looking at it: $AAPL share price is an exchange ratio vs. #USD, similar to a for-stock merger. The "number of shares out" of #USD has gone up since Feb 12, so the exchange ratio needs to be adjusted accordingly. Without this adjustment, $AAPL would be quoted far lower.

5/ Today's activists are not too dissimilar from Tesla shorts. Yes, $TSLA may not be worth its market quotation, but it would never have amounted to *anything* in the hands of activists. Back in the day at $AAPL, today's activists might have replaced Steve Jobs with John Sculley.

4/ The problem is that activists are working with too much capital, and they think they know better than the likes of @jack. This is a loser's mindset. It's like thinking you can figure out how to make Sears competitive versus Amazon. Good luck.
